reviewText: Frasier himself returns for a sixteenth season in the fall of 1999. By then,Kelsey Grammer was previously nominated for and had won a multitude of Emmys for the legendary role. During the 1999-2000 season,Grammer's fans couldn't get enough of the hilarious and somewhat wacky psyhiatrist. By then,Frasier was already syndicated(7 days a week) on a multitude of independent stations all over America and other countries as well.

reviewerName: John D. Muir "oldies and pies lover"
reviewText: This is my favorite Frasier season, though they are all excellent. By this point in the show's long run its success was established and the writers took the opportunity to take it a bit further, with surreal humor and a wonderfully satisfying development of the Niles/Daphne love story. One of the show's real strengths is the laugh-out-loud one-liners, sometimes slipped in subtly so you have to think for a moment before getting the joke, and this season abounds in those.The main characters are as solid as always and there is the usual array of accomplished guest stars, including Daphne's brother Simon, played by Anthony LaPaglia, who is hilarious although strangely seems to come from a different part of England than Daphne and her mother. Daphne's mother is played by Millicent Martin and those of us with long memories remember her singing the theme song to 'That Was The Week That Was', the show hosted by the late David Frost which introduced satire to the UK.This series was one that got all the relationships between the five main characters exactly right and that is fully in evidence here. A brilliant concept realized to the utmost in this season.
summary: As Frasier would say- nutty, fruity, with a hint of sauce.
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: Well, the "Frasier" team .. even in season 7 .. was witty, subtle .. and productive (in the better sense). Please give credit to the writers .. and the comedians/comediennes .. and the overall, very-high quality of how a spin-off (of "Cheers") could make it's own niche, in the old sit-com part of originality.
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: This was the last "good" Frasier season, and it's sort of sad to watch.Writing is what made the series what it was, and the writing here continues the decline first seen in Season 5.But the most telling development is, of course, Niles and Daphne.  This robbed the series of so much of its unique energy, and signalled to its fans that change is not always good.Are there high spots here?  Sure.  Martin goes through some interesting stuff, and I'm one of the four or five fans who actually like Daphne's lawyer fiance.  But, overall, one watches this one because...well...one has to, I suppose.
summary: Better Than Bad, Worse than Best
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: 'Frasier' was unassailably one of the ten best series of all time. But the creaking in its structure that began with season six became an ominous rattling in this year's collection. It was the last season for which I didn't miss a first-run episode and that was very telling to me.Here is where the writing shortfall began. Much of the characterization devolved into either inconsistency (poor Roz) or self-parody (Niles's out-of-the-blue bug phobia). And the increased poaching of gags and scenes from previous seasons became glaringly obvious. Most series lose much of their steam after three or four years but 'Frasier' maintained superb output through six and that's very commendable.Then it became 'Three's Company' and ... well, not so commendable. You can call it French farce all you like but it's still lazy writing in the long term.Still, as I say in my title, this show on a bad day beats ninety-five percent of other sitcoms at their best. I own it, don't I?
summary: Bad 'Frasier' still better than good 'According to Jim'
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: This season has few lulls and every episode is great and memorable.  It is also the first season where Daphne learns about Niles' feelings for her.  Daphne and Donny are planning to marry and Simon, Daphne's brother makes a visit.  One of the funniest episodes is when the Cranes go on a trip to Oregon in a Winnebago.  Niles crawls in the wrong the Winnebago at a rest stop and gets taken on a long trip, then steals it.  All so the guys can celebrate the millennium in a cabin in the country.

reviewText: Not for everyone, but I love these shows.  They have a strange, witty sense of humor. Of course,the "gruff" Martin is the perfect catalyst for the two "refined" sons.  Kelsey G. is at his best, and is made better by the supporting cast.  Each character is developed in relation to the others, allowing an interaction that is truly satisfying to watch.
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: For diehard "Frasier" fans, Season 7 represents a highpoint as the long awaited Niles/Daphne relationship finally culminates in "Something Borrowed, Something Blue" and leads to the best cliffhanger in the series.The best episodes of the season all have either veteran or new character actors featured in some wonderful episodes. Lilith returns in "The Apparent Trap", with Frederick doing all he can to manipulate his parents into giving him a mini-bike.  "The Dog That Rocks The Cradle" brings back a finger-dislocating Bulldog and is really a howler. And Frasier's notorious agent Bebe makes "Morning Comes Entertainment" (a wonderful episode title) a sheer delight.  The image of her 'n Frasier riding on a donkey while Niles proclaims, "Via con Dios." is very funny.Let's not forget the newcomers to the series as well, like the irrepressable Jean Smart in "Big Crane on Campus", she's both beautiful and frightening at the same time.  Kim Coles is delightful in "Something About Dr. Mary", an episode that addresses the issue of Frasier's inability to tell Mary the truth because she's black. Which is interesting considering that very few African-Americans have ever been on "Frasier".  But the real star is Anthony LaPaglia as Daphne's wayward, drunken brother Simon.  He is terrific in back to back episodes ("Dark Side of the Moon", "Something Borrowed, Something Blue").Despite some very good episodes, it's clear that the writers were running out of ideas during this season as several shows repeat themes or even lift parts of previous episodes.  Take for example "Hot Pursuit", which vitually remakes Season 3's "Roz Loves Frasier", although this version is slower and unnecessary. "Rivals" uses the same ballroom set as Season 3's "Moon Dance" and even has a tango. And "Out With Dad" reworks Season 2's "The Matchmaker", even Daphne's cackling in the kitchen is identical to Martin's laugh in "The Matchmaker".It should be noted that Paramount has apparently listened to the hues 'n cries of the masses as Disc 1 gives the viewer a choice of either previews or the menu page, unlike Season's 4, 5, 'n 6 when you had to no choice but to skip through the previews.I really enjoyed this Season even more than I remembered when it originally ran on NBC and it's argueably better than the erratic Season 6.  In fact, had the "Frasier" series ended with Daphne 'n Niles driving off to a new destiny, it might have been the perfect ending.  Oh well, this DVD collection stands on it's own and is a welcome addition to the "Frasier" family.Enjoy!Tidbits:- GOOF: In "Something About Dr. Mary", Daphne injures her RIGHT wrist after Niles accidently kicks her in the behind (a very funny scene). Later on, we see the bandage on her right wrist. But during the stinger, the bandage is now on Daphne's LEFT wrist.- Rebecca Schull turns in a very un-"Fey" like performance in "RDWRER".  She's becomes the second "Wings" star to appear on "Frasier".- "Fight Before Christmas" has another first for the Frasier series, the title card introducing the "Wassling" uses a different typeface for the first time.- GOOF: In "Dark Side of the Moon", Daphne clears all the trash 'n beer cans off the coffee table and then stands up just before Frasier enters. When we see the coffee table again, a beer can and some trash magically reappear.- The stinger for "Something Borrowed, Something Blue" is the first one NOT to have any actors in it (apart from the "Thanks for Calling" stingers that usually appear during the last episode of the season).  All we see is a darkened set.
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: I love this show. The acting is just perfect and funny! If you are looking for fun and light show to watch this is it. You will fall in love with the characters, my favorite is "Niles"
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: Its interesting to me how well these episodes are holding up. The Donny, Mel, and Regan characters were my least favorite. Out of the entire series, this season was probably the lowest point to me. Yet, even at its lowest point, the Frasier series still delivers! During this time in its run, I quit watching the show, and now I see that it was still good after all. From what I read from other Frasier fans, the last two seasons of Frasier really took off again and were up to par with the show's standards. I'm not a critic, but I play one on the computer.The one and only "Minus" for me is there is no Special Features again!!! Is it too costly to get a hold of some of the cast members and do a 5 to 10 min interview? Or better yet, get some of the cast together to watch an episode or two. Its always a great treat to hear the cast comment about episodes. They do that on the Dukes of Hazzard DVD's and it works out really well. You get to hear some behind the scenes stuff. Sometimes the stars surprise each other with new information. I would enjoy hearing from Kelsey, David, or John to get there impressions on the DVD's themselves. Do they like them? Or, Do they own any? I hope for Season 8 the studio will try to get some special features together for us Frasier fansEven though, personally, this season is not my most favorite, it is still very entertaining. I believe all of us Frasier fans are grateful to have the episodes availabe on DVD.
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: A strong opening to the season with Momma Mia, Father of The Bride, Radio Wars, and the craziness continues. There are many new discoveries and further awareness for our loveable characters. The highlights are Kenny`s reaction to Frasier`s pompous conducting in his ever-growing orchestra of episode `They`re Playing Our Song` and what a song! Other highlights include the episode where Martin plays gay in every way and Niles joins the fun with a dramatic diva exit! Also the zaniness of `What`s Wrong With Dr. Mary?` while Roz produces Gil's show, Frasier takes on a new producer who ends up hosting with him and giving advice that borders on adolescence. Meanwhile the new love of Niles' life is a bitch from hell called Mel who's got her clutches on him and takes on the Cranes and Daphne with insults during brunch at Frasier's in `The Whine Club' and of course all the jitters and doubts before Daphne's wedding! Classic Frasier!!
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: Frasier is one of the most unusual and exceptional comedy TV shows, not because of its premise, but because of its superb writing, terrific ensemble cast, and fantastic set of directors, screenwriters, and producers. Noting some 37 Emmy awards gathered over its 11-year run to support that claim, all I can say is that, even after 150 episodes (which brings us about to the end of Season Seven), the show remains consistently hilarious, touching, and absorbing in nearly every aspect. Not since The Dick Van Dyke Show have we seen a show like this, which seems to have taken the 100-show rule (the rule-of-thumb that states that any show, regardless of how good, cannot generally keep the quality "up" beyond 100 shows without resorting to increasingly goofy and implausible episodes) and thrown in right out the window. And even though Carl Reiner ended The Dick Van Dyke Show in 1965 at the height of its popularity because he full well understood this reality, Frasier seems to have demonstrated that the rule is not an absolute, and although incredibly rare, a show could indeed break that "rule."I won't give any spoilers, and therefore won't even attempt to describe in any detail what happens in the show, but I can say that Frasier is a radio talk-show psychiatrist who lives with his retired father in a posh high-rise in Seattle. Frasier spends much time with his brother, Niles, and retains for his father a live-in health care provider, Daphne, who is more a member of the family than anything else. The show takes place primarily at home at at "Cafe Nervosa," a favorite coffee shop, but numerous scenes also take place at the radio station and a select venue of external settings. Due the to development of the story line, the show is best enjoyed right from the beginning of Season One, and then watched in order over time, across the Seasons. This is a show that relies of witty banter, irony, and lampooning, and you have to stay on your toes and listen carefully if you are to catch it all. Be prepared to be rolling in laughter through the entire thing.Beyond the level of comic performance achievement in the show, there are some other aspects of the series that are also unusual. For example, the very first episode, the pilot, was hilarious, something not normally seen in a first episode of a show when the cast and crew are trying to get things figured out. Not here, however; the laughs start at scene one, and never let up from that point on. Another aspect of the show that is also quite unusual is that, amongst all the jokes, there is a punctuated series of emotional and powerfully moving scenes that intermittently show up ever few episodes.And (how can I possible not mention this, as those who have seen the show already know), "Frasier" carries within its story line one of the most moving love stories ever seen on television. It's a love story that takes eleven years to come to fruition, but its it is one of the most powerful to have ever been seen on the small screen. Don't think you can break down and cry in the middle of a comedy show? Millions of people who watched Frasier over the years, laughing hysterically, also wiped the tears from their eyes over this love story. You may, too.Five stars in every respect, including the cast, the writers, the directors. Even "Eddie," comes across as one of the most accomplished animal actors since "Mr. Ed."Note:The digital transfer to DVD for Frasier is not among the best, with some banding and noise present in many scenes. Compare this with, say, the digital transfer to Get Smart (1965-70), which is so clear that it almost seems to be an early version of Blu-Ray. Frasier is not like that at all, but it's not that big of a deal. Audio quality is excellent. But its the story and the show that carries the day. You'll instantly forget any imperfections as you get pulled into the story and the laughter.Also--and I wish I had looked into this more carefully in the beginning--you can save a fair amount of money by purchasing the entire Frasier 11 seasons at one time (I think the savings is about 30 dollars from purchasing each set individually). See it here:Frasier: The Complete Series
summary: World-Class Comedy Keeps It Up All the Way through Seven Years!
Title: Frasier: Season 7

reviewText: The seventh season of "Frasier" has some really good episodes in it, but then again, that's not really a surprise.This season is probably my favorite, mostly because Niles finally finally FINALLY ends up with Daphne, after a highly-medicated Frasier tells Daphne how Niles feels about her.  (This episode is really good, but its title currently escapes me.)This season is also great because one of my very favorite episodes is on this set, and the episode is "Rdwrer".  In this episode, Frasier, Niles and Martin go off in Martin's Winnebago (a. k. a. the "Road Warrior") for a new year's celebration in Idaho.  However, during a brief stop during the trip, Niles accidentally enters the wrong RV, and a farce ensues.I also like "The Apparent Trap", the episode where Lilith and Frederick come for Thanksgiving--particularly the part where Niles attempts to play a video game.Anyway, this season is great, and I highly recommend it.
summary: So this is why "7" is a lucky number...
Title: Frasier: Season 7
